results.title: In the name of the crow
results.creator_credit: Peter Kordyl, Mark Bin Bakar, Marion Benjamin, Robert Bropho, Heather Williams and Excalibur Nominees
results.brief_description: Most tourists who visit Rottnest Island are unaware of its history. Established as a prison for Aboriginal men around 1840, it was intended as a place for “rehabilitation”. However, accounts of floggings, chainings and hangings flourished on the mainland despite official enquiries and commissions suggesting everything was in order. In this documentary, Robert Bropho takes us to the island and traces the hardship and the suffering of his ancestors that has been omitted from white man’s history.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Peter Kordyl, Mark Bin Bakar, Marion Benjamin, Robert Bropho, Heather Williams and Excalibur Nominees

results.title: Night cries: a rural tragedy
results.creator_credit: Tracey Moffatt, Penny McDonald and AFTRS
results.brief_description: In the red glow of the outback an Aboriginal woman nurses her ill white mother. As we watch the old woman dying her daughter confronts the finality of death; the bitterness of memory. Shot entirely in a studio “Night cries” uses a stark set-design, a palette of colours as from a dream, and a haunting soundtrack: of bush noises, gasping breath, the wail of a dingo, to suggest a world that combines the frightening distortion of a nightmare and the painful isolation of human loss. Subtitled “a rural tragedy” the film’s portrayal of a personal agony illuminates and exposes the general horror of Australia’s race history. With Marcia Langton, Agnes Hardwick and Jimmy Little.

results.title: Boomalli: five Koorie artists
results.creator_credit: Michael Riley, Paul Humfress and Film Australia
results.brief_description: Boomalli is an artists’ co-operative - a collection of photographers, painters, sculptors, designers and filmmakers, who are urban Aboriginal or Koorie artists. The work presented ranges from that of fashion designer Bronwyn Bancroft, the sand sculpture of Fiona Foley, Tracey Moffatt’s film, “Nice coloured girls” and the paintings of Raymond Meeks and Jeffrey Samuals. This visually rich and inspiring film is about their work. Their achievements speak for themselves.

results.title: Dreamings : the art of Aboriginal Australia
results.creator_credit: Michael Riley, Janet Bell and Film Australia
results.brief_description: Dreamings is a journey into the lush mangroves and scarred heartlands of Australia to see traditional aboriginal artists at work. From the air we view some of the landforms and waterways incorporated in the imagery of paintings by Michael Nelson Jakamarra. He talks of his family’s association with the land and his intrinsic faith in spiritual connections with animals and plants. Our voyage continues to the Great Western Desert and a sacred waterhole. This program begins to unravel some of the mysteries behind creations of immense artistic beauty.

results.title: Nice coloured girls
results.brief_description: Nice Coloured Girls uses experimental film techniques in an examination of the new urban ritual of taking white men for a ride. No longer the victims of these men, the women are still trapped by economic necessity. “Nice Coloured Girls” uses a clever juxtaposition of images and voice over of extracts from early journals of white settlers to compare aspects of the relationship between Aboriginal women and white men in the past and in the 1980s. Cast includes Gayle Mabo, Cheryl Pit, Janelle Court, Fiona George and Lindsay McCorrmack. (Awards: London, Berlin, Toronto)

results.title: Cass: no saucepan diver
results.creator_credit: Wayne Barker and Australian Institute of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Studies
results.brief_description: In 1982 Aboriginal filmmaker Wayne Barker returned to his home in Broome, Western Australia to make a film about his grandfather, Cass Drummond. The result is this personal portrait of a staunchly self-reliant old man as he looks back on his life in the pearling industry and comments on what it was like to be an Aboriginal earlier this century.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Wayne Barker and Australian Institute of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Studies

results.title: Neighbours (the remix) - Destiny Deacon (Over d-Fence)
results.brief_description: A half-hour program that references the global success of the soap-opera Neighbours. Consisting of three nine-minute segments by an emerging documentarian, an emerging fiction moving image maker, and by a visual artist, Neighbours (the remix) will playfully subvert and imaginatively redraw the landscape of Australia suburbia. As part of Neighbours (the remix) there will be interspersed ad-breaks (30 second duration each) by five leading, established art practitioners.

results.title: Range of experience
results.creator_credit: Anne Pratten, Lisa Duff, Marc Gillezeau, Maryella Hatfield and AFTRS
results.brief_description:
It is the future - a world where the ability to experience life’s basic emotions has been lost to humanity and Virtual Reality has replaced dreams. The company Range of Experience Productions Inc has invented the Dream Base Selector, a machine which enables users to re-live experiences once created naturally by the subconscious mind. But it soon becomes apparent that the technology is slightly faulty…
Cast: Soledad Cordeaux
